**Transcript**:
If you're ever walking down the street and come across an oddly stretched out
image, like this, you'll have an opportunity
to see something remarkable, but only if you stand in exactly
the right spot. That happens because these works
employ a technique called anamorphosis. Anamorphosis is a special case
of perspective art, where artists represent realistic
three-dimensional views on two-dimensional surfaces. Though it's common today, this kind of perspective drawing has only
been around since the Italian Renaissance. Ancient art often showed all figures
on the same plane, varying in size by symbolic importance. Classical Greek and Roman artists realized
they could make objects seem further by drawing them smaller, but many early attempts at perspective
were inconsistent or incorrect. In 15th century Florence, artists realized the illusion 
of perspective could be achieved with higher degrees
of sophistication by applying mathematical principles. In 1485, Leonardo da Vinci 
manipulated the mathematics to create the first known 
anamorphic drawing. A number of other artists later
picked up the technique, including Hans Holbein 
in "The Ambassadors." This painting features a distorted
shape that forms into a skull as the viewer approaches from the side. In order to understand how artists
achieve that effect, we first have to understand how 
perspective drawings work in general. Imagine looking out a window. Light bounces off objects 
and into your eye, intersecting the window along the way. Now, imagine you could paint the image
you see directly onto the window while standing still and keeping
only one eye open. The result would be nearly
indistinguishable from the actual view with your brain adding depth
to the 2-D picture, but only from that one spot. Standing even just a bit off
to the side would make the drawing 
lose its 3-D effect. Artists understand that 
a perspective drawing is just a projection
onto a 2-D plane. This allows them to use math to come up
with basic rules of perspective that allow them to draw without a window. One is that parallel lines, like these, can only be drawn as parallel if they're
parallel to the plane of the canvas. Otherwise, they need to be drawn
converging to a common point known as the vanishing point. So that's a standard perspective drawing. With an anamorphic drawing,
like "The Ambassadors," directly facing the canvas makes the image
look stretched and distorted, but put your eye in exactly the right spot
way off to the side, and the skull materializes. Going back to the window analogy, it's as if the artist painted 
onto a window positioned at an angle instead of straight on, though that's not how Renaissance artists
actually created anamorphic drawings. Typically, they draw a normal image 
onto one surface, then use a light, a grid, or even strings to project it
onto a canvas at an angle. Now let's say you want to make
an anamorphic sidewalk drawing. In this case, you want to create
the illusion that a 3-D image has been added
seamlessly into an existing scene. You can first put a window
in front of the sidewalk and draw what you want to add 
onto the window. It should be in the same perspective
as the rest of the scene, which might require the use of those
basic rules of perspective. Once the drawing's complete, you can use a projector placed 
where your eye was to project your drawing down 
onto the sidewalk, then chalk over it. The sidewalk drawing 
and the drawing on the window will be nearly indistinguishable
from that point of view, so viewers' brains will again be tricked into believing that the drawing
on the ground is three-dimensional. And you don't have to project onto
a flat surface to create this illusion. You can project onto multiple surfaces, or assemble a jumble of objects,
that from the right point of view, appears to be something else entirely. All over the planet, you can find
solid surfaces giving way to strange, wonderful,
or terrifying visions. From your sidewalk 
to your computer screen, these are just some of the ways
that math and perspective can open up whole new worlds.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: How do artists physically create anamorphisms?
Options: A. By using a projector, B. By using strings, C. By using a grid, D. All of the above
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is anamorphosis, and how does it differ from perspective art? Options: A. Anamorphosis is a technique that represents realistic three-dimensional views on two-dimensional surfaces, whereas perspective art represents two-dimensional views., B. Anamorphosis is a type of perspective art that uses mathematical principles to create the illusion of depth., C. Anamorphosis is a technique that represents three-dimensional views on two-dimensional surfaces, whereas perspective art represents two-dimensional views., D. Anamorphosis is a technique that uses a grid or strings to project an image onto a canvas at an angle. Correct Option: C
Question 2: Which artist is credited with creating the first known anamorphic drawing in 1485? Options: A. Leonardo da Vinci, B. Hans Holbein, C. Michelangelo, D. Raphael Correct Option: A
Question 3: What is the purpose of using a vanishing point in perspective drawing? Options: A. To create a sense of depth, B. To make objects appear smaller, C. To make objects appear larger, D. To create a sense of perspective Correct Option: A
Question 4: How can artists achieve the effect of an anamorphic drawing, such as "The Ambassadors"? Options: A. By drawing a normal image onto one surface and then using a light, a grid, or strings to project it onto a canvas at an angle., B. By using a projector to project the image onto the canvas., C. By using a camera to take a photograph of the image., D. By using a computer to create the image. Correct Option: A
Question 5: What is the difference between a perspective drawing and an anamorphic drawing? Options: A. A perspective drawing is a two-dimensional representation of a three-dimensional scene, while an anamorphic drawing is a three-dimensional representation of a two-dimensional scene., B. A perspective drawing is a two-dimensional representation of a two-dimensional scene, while an anamorphic drawing is a three-dimensional representation of a three-dimensional scene., C. A perspective drawing is a two-dimensional representation of a three-dimensional scene, while an anamorphic drawing is a two-dimensional representation of a two-dimensional scene., D. A perspective drawing is a three-dimensional representation of a three-dimensional scene, while an anamorphic drawing is a two-dimensional representation of a two-dimensional scene. Correct Option: A
Question 6: What is the purpose of using a window in front of the sidewalk to create an anamorphic sidewalk drawing? Options: A. To create a sense of depth, B. To make objects appear smaller, C. To make objects appear larger, D. To project the drawing onto the sidewalk Correct Option: D
Question 7: How can artists create the illusion that a 3-D image has been added seamlessly into an existing scene? Options: A. By using a projector to project the image onto the scene., B. By using a camera to take a photograph of the scene., C. By drawing a normal image onto one surface and then using a light, a grid, or strings to project it onto a canvas at an angle., D. By using a computer to create the image. Correct Option: C
Question 8: What is the significance of the vanishing point in anamorphic drawing? Options: A. It creates a sense of depth, B. It makes objects appear smaller, C. It makes objects appear larger, D. It creates a sense of perspective Correct Option: A
Question 9: How can artists use math and perspective to create the illusion of depth in a two-dimensional image? Options: A. By using a projector to project the image onto a canvas., B. By using a camera to take a photograph of the image., C. By drawing a normal image onto one surface and then using a light, a grid, or strings to project it onto a canvas at an angle., D. By using a computer to create the image. Correct Option: C
Question 10: What is the purpose of using a projector to project the drawing onto the sidewalk in an anamorphic sidewalk drawing? Options: A. To create a sense of depth, B. To make objects appear smaller, C. To make objects appear larger, D. To project the drawing onto the sidewalk Correct Option: D
Question 11: What is the key concept behind creating an anamorphic drawing? Options: A. Using a single vanishing point, B. Using multiple vanishing points, C. Projecting an image onto a surface at an angle, D. Using a computer to create the image Correct Option: C
Question 12: How can artists achieve the effect of a 3D image in a 2D drawing? Options: A. By using a single color, B. By using a single shape, C. By using perspective and math to create a sense of depth, D. By using a projector to project the image Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 4. 

This question asks "How can artists achieve the effect of an anamorphic drawing, such as 'The Ambassadors'?" and the correct option is "By drawing a normal image onto one surface and then using a light, a grid, or strings to project it onto a canvas at an angle." 

This question is similar to the ground truth MCQ, which asks "How do artists physically create anamorphisms?" and has the correct option "All of the above" with options including "By using a projector", "By using strings", and "By using a grid". 

Although the wording of the questions is not identical, the intent and content of the questions are similar, and the correct options both describe the use of a grid, strings, or projection to create an anamorphic drawing. 

Therefore, the index of the most similar generated MCQ is 4.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 5, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
There's a lot of buzz in the news about de-extinction. With the growing interest in technologies and research, that could possibly bring animals and plants back from being, well, extinct. One of the candidates high on that list is the woolly mammoth. They're the closest relatives to our living Asian elephants today, and only widely disappeared about 10,000 years ago. With some isolated populations hanging on until about 4,700 years ago. That may seem like a long time, but at that period in the not-so-distant past, glass was being invented and the great pyramids of Giza were being built. So, really, it's a blip in the scheme of things. Since woolly mammoth's genetic information has been so well preserved in the permafrost, where recent specimens have been discovered, scientists have been able to sequence their genomes and now different groups are trying to figure out a way to insert mammoth genes into living elephant cells and maybe, in a way, bring them back. But my question is, why mammoths? Why not, say, mastodons? No, not the heavy metal group, the late miocene megafauna. Modern day elephants, mammoths and mastodons are all in the order proboscidea, along with other exinct tusked creatures, like palaeomastodons and gomphotheres. From the outside, mammoths and mastodons may look pretty similar, but they've been different for a very long time. About 25 million years. Mastodons were on Earth long before the mammoths, who showed up a little late to the Pleistocene party about 20 million years later. So you couldn't hope to have good luck splicing mastodon DNA into the Asian elephant genome. That's like putting human cells into a gibbon. It wouldn't work because the two are too genetically different. In addition to genetic differences between mammoths and mastodons, they're also morphologically different. This is most obviously seen in their teeth. Mammoths have large, flat, grinding surfaces on top of their molars, whereas mastodons have giant, mountain-like cusps. These cusps even inspired their scientific name, from the Greek word "masto" for "breast" and "odon" for "tooth." Literally breast tooth. The shape of their teeth gives us clues about their diets, too. Mammoths were grazers, like cows and elephants today and as such, they have flat grinding surfaces on their teeth for breaking down grasses. Mastodons were browsers, like goats. The bulbous cusps on their teeth were useful for breaking down sticks and shrubs. So, remember, mammoths: cows. Matsodons: breast-toothed goats. In addition to differences in their dentition, mastodons were shorter stockier than mammoths with smaller ears, but there were some exceptions. Mammoths and mastodons are in two different genera, Mammut and Mammuthus. There were four different mastodon species and ten different species of mammoth. You're probably most familiar with the woolly mammoth but there was also a pygmy species, the dwarf mammoth, which was about as tall as I am. This species was found on the Channel Islands off of California and its small size was most likely result of island dwarfism. This can happen when a large species gets isolated on an island, since smaller animals require fewer food resources, and in the absence of predators, small animals tend to breed more quickly than their larger counterparts. As to how they got to the island, how else? They swam! Elephants today are great long-distance swimmers with their built-in snorkels and buoyant mass. Smelling delicious grasses from mainland California, a group of Columbian mammoths departed the coast, swimming out into the ocean towards the smell. Fast forward 30,000 years and congratulations! Almost puppy sized mammoths. While there isn't yet a conclusive answer as to what caused the extinction for both mammoths and mastodons in the last 10,000 years, whether it was from over-hunting by humans or climate related changes, a few questions remain. If we can resurrect the mammoth genome, should we? And where would we put them?

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: The Woolly Mammoth went extinct 10,000 years ago. What else was happening at this same time?
Options: A. The dinosaurs were going extinct, B. The Gutenberg press was invented, C. Glass was being invented
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: Why are scientists focusing on bringing back the woolly mammoth rather than the mastodon? Options: A. Mammoths are closer relatives to modern-day Asian elephants and have better-preserved genetic information., B. Mastodons were on Earth long before mammoths., C. Mammoths and mastodons have similar genetic differences that make it easier to bring back mammoths., D. Mammoths have a more diverse range of species. Correct Option: A
Question 2: What is the main difference in the diets of mammoths and mastodons, as indicated by the shape of their teeth? Options: A. Mammoths had large, flat grinding surfaces for breaking down grasses, whereas mastodons had giant, mountain-like cusps for breaking down sticks and shrubs., B. Mastodons had large, flat grinding surfaces for breaking down grasses., C. Mammoths were browsers, like goats., D. Mastodons were grazers, like cows and elephants today. Correct Option: A
Question 3: What is the term for the process by which a large species becomes smaller when isolated on an island, requiring fewer food resources? Options: A. Island gigantism., B. Island dwarfism., C. Genetic drift., D. Speciation. Correct Option: B
Question 4: Why did the pygmy mammoths on the Channel Islands become so small? Options: A. They were hunted by humans., B. They were isolated on the island for a long time and experienced island dwarfism., C. They were unable to adapt to the island environment., D. They were a result of genetic mutation. Correct Option: B
Question 5: What is the scientific name for the genus of mastodons? Options: A. Mammuthus., B. Mammut., C. Proboscidea., D. Mastodonidae. Correct Option: B
Question 6: Which of the following is NOT a characteristic of mastodons compared to mammoths? Options: A. Mastodons had smaller ears., B. Mastodons had giant, mountain-like cusps on their teeth., C. Mastodons were grazers., D. Mastodons were shorter and stockier. Correct Option: C
Question 7: How did the pygmy mammoths on the Channel Islands likely get to the island? Options: A. They were brought there by humans., B. They swam from the mainland., C. They were transported by a natural disaster., D. They evolved from a different species. Correct Option: B
Question 8: What is the term for the process of bringing back extinct species through genetic engineering? Options: A. De-extinction., B. Genetic engineering., C. Speciation., D. Evolution. Correct Option: A
Question 9: Why is it difficult to splice mastodon DNA into the Asian elephant genome? Options: A. Mastodons and Asian elephants have similar genetic information., B. Mastodons and Asian elephants are too genetically different., C. Mastodons and Asian elephants have the same range of species., D. Mastodons and Asian elephants have the same diet. Correct Option: B
Question 10: What is the main question remaining in the debate about whether to bring back the woolly mammoth? Options: A. Should we bring back the woolly mammoth?, B. What would be the consequences of bringing back the woolly mammoth?, C. What caused the extinction of mammoths and mastodons?, D. How did the pygmy mammoths get to the Channel Islands? Correct Option: B


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
None of the generated MCQs directly match the ground truth MCQ in terms of question content and options. However, Question 1 is the closest match in terms of discussing the time period of the woolly mammoth's extinction, but it does not specifically mention other events happening at the same time.

A more suitable match would be a question that mentions the time period of 10,000 years ago and the events that occurred during that time. Unfortunately, none of the generated MCQs meet this criteria.

However, if I had to choose the most similar generated MCQ based on the available options, I would say that none of the generated MCQs are a good match.

But if you insist on an answer, I would say that Question 1 is the closest match, but it's not a good match.

But my question is, why mammoths? Why not, say, mastodons? No, not the heavy metal group, the late miocene megafauna. Modern day elephants, mammoths and mastodons are all in the order proboscidea, along with other exinct tusked creatures, like palaeomastodons and gomphotheres. From the outside, mammoths and mastodons may look pretty similar, but they've been different for a very long time. About 25 million years. Mastodons were on Earth long before the mammoths, who showed up a little late to the Pleistocene party about 20 million years later. So you couldn't hope to have good luck splicing mastodon DNA into the Asian elephant genome. That's like putting human cells into a gibbon. **Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Though Mastodons and Woolly Mammoths look similar, genetically they're very different. How older is the Mastodon species?
Options: A. 10,000 years, B. 50,000, C. 1,000,000, D. 20,000,000 years
Correct Option: D

Correct Option: B

Question 6: Which of the following is NOT a characteristic of mastodons compared to mammoths? Options: A. Mastodons had smaller ears., B. Mastodons had giant, mountain-like cusps on their teeth., C. Mastodons were grazers., D. Mastodons were shorter and stockier. Correct Option: C
Question 7: How did the pygmy mammoths on the Channel Islands likely get to the island? Options: A. They were brought there by humans., B. They swam from the mainland., C. They were transported by a natural disaster., D. They evolved from a different species. Correct Option: B
Question 8: What is the term for the process of bringing back extinct species through genetic engineering? Options: A. De-extinction., B. Genetic engineering., C. Speciation., D. Evolution. Correct Option: A
Question 9: Why is it difficult to splice mastodon DNA into the Asian elephant genome? Options: A. Mastodons and Asian elephants have similar genetic information., B. Mastodons and Asian elephants are too genetically different., C. Mastodons and Asian elephants have the same range of species., D. Mastodons and Asian elephants have the same diet. Correct Option: B
Question 10: What is the main question remaining in the debate about whether to bring back the woolly mammoth? Options: A. Should we bring back the woolly mammoth?, B. What would be the consequences of bringing back the woolly mammoth?, C. What caused the extinction of mammoths and mastodons?, D. How did the pygmy mammoths get to the Channel Islands? Correct Option: B

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 5, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
There's a lot of buzz in the news about de-extinction. With the growing interest in technologies and research, that could possibly bring animals and plants back from being, well, extinct. One of the candidates high on that list is the woolly mammoth. They're the closest relatives to our living Asian elephants today, and only widely disappeared about 10,000 years ago. With some isolated populations hanging on until about 4,700 years ago. That may seem like a long time, but at that period in the not-so-distant past, glass was being invented and the great pyramids of Giza were being built. So, really, it's a blip in the scheme of things. Since woolly mammoth's genetic information has been so well preserved in the permafrost, where recent specimens have been discovered, scientists have been able to sequence their genomes and now different groups are trying to figure out a way to insert mammoth genes into living elephant cells and maybe, in a way, bring them back. But my question is, why mammoths? Why not, say, mastodons? No, not the heavy metal group, the late miocene megafauna. Modern day elephants, mammoths and mastodons are all in the order proboscidea, along with other exinct tusked creatures, like palaeomastodons and gomphotheres. From the outside, mammoths and mastodons may look pretty similar, but they've been different for a very long time. About 25 million years. Mastodons were on Earth long before the mammoths, who showed up a little late to the Pleistocene party about 20 million years later. So you couldn't hope to have good luck splicing mastodon DNA into the Asian elephant genome. That's like putting human cells into a gibbon. It wouldn't work because the two are too genetically different. In addition to genetic differences between mammoths and mastodons, they're also morphologically different. This is most obviously seen in their teeth. Mammoths have large, flat, grinding surfaces on top of their molars, whereas mastodons have giant, mountain-like cusps. These cusps even inspired their scientific name, from the Greek word "masto" for "breast" and "odon" for "tooth." Literally breast tooth. The shape of their teeth gives us clues about their diets, too. Mammoths were grazers, like cows and elephants today and as such, they have flat grinding surfaces on their teeth for breaking down grasses. Mastodons were browsers, like goats. The bulbous cusps on their teeth were useful for breaking down sticks and shrubs. So, remember, mammoths: cows. Matsodons: breast-toothed goats. In addition to differences in their dentition, mastodons were shorter stockier than mammoths with smaller ears, but there were some exceptions. Mammoths and mastodons are in two different genera, Mammut and Mammuthus. There were four different mastodon species and ten different species of mammoth. You're probably most familiar with the woolly mammoth but there was also a pygmy species, the dwarf mammoth, which was about as tall as I am. This species was found on the Channel Islands off of California and its small size was most likely result of island dwarfism. This can happen when a large species gets isolated on an island, since smaller animals require fewer food resources, and in the absence of predators, small animals tend to breed more quickly than their larger counterparts. As to how they got to the island, how else? They swam! Elephants today are great long-distance swimmers with their built-in snorkels and buoyant mass. Smelling delicious grasses from mainland California, a group of Columbian mammoths departed the coast, swimming out into the ocean towards the smell. Fast forward 30,000 years and congratulations! Almost puppy sized mammoths. While there isn't yet a conclusive answer as to what caused the extinction for both mammoths and mastodons in the last 10,000 years, whether it was from over-hunting by humans or climate related changes, a few questions remain. If we can resurrect the mammoth genome, should we? And where would we put them?

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Though Mastodons and Woolly Mammoths look similar, genetically they're very different. How older is the Mastodon species?
Options: A. 10,000 years, B. 50,000, C. 1,000,000, D. 20,000,000 years
Correct Option: D

Question 1: Why are scientists focusing on bringing back the woolly mammoth rather than the mastodon? Options: A. Mammoths and mastodons have similar genetic differences that make it easier to bring back mammoths., D. Mammoths have a more diverse range of species. Correct Option: A

Mastodons had large, flat grinding surfaces for breaking down grasses., C. Mammoths were browsers, like goats., D. Mastodons were grazers, like cows and elephants today. Correct Option: A

They were isolated on the island for a long time and experienced island dwarfism., C. They were unable to adapt to the island environment., D. They were a result of genetic mutation. Correct Option: B

Question 7: How did the pygmy mammoths on the Channel Islands likely get to the island? Options: A. They were brought there by humans., B. They swam from the mainland., C. They were transported by a natural disaster., D. They evolved from a different species. Correct Option: B

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 7, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Why do skunks smell so bad? It all comes down to chemistry. By the way, this video will include slow motion
footage of skunk anuses. So, be warned. I’m Anna Rothschild, and this is Gross Science. There are a number of species of skunk in
the world, but the most iconic has to be the striped skunk. That’s the one that looks like Pepe Le Pew—it’s
all black, typically with one white line that usually splits into two on its back. And it can be found all over the United States
as well as northern Mexico and southern Canada. Its latin name is Mephitis mephitis, which
appropriately enough means something like foul stench or noxious vapor. Obviously, that’s because the most defining
character of skunks is their defensive spray, which can cause watery eyes, nausea, and leave
you smelling terrible. The chemical makeup of the spray is different
depending on the species, but all of them contain special types of compounds called
“thiols.” Thiols, also known as “mercaptans,” are
a type of chemical group made up of a sulfur and hydrogen atom bonded together. And they typically smell really strongly. There are actually three different thiols
in striped skunks spray, and two of those are the main contributors to the awful odor. But three other molecules in the spray are
what are called “thioacetates.” Those compounds don’t have a strong scent,
but they can easily become thiols when they’re exposed to water. And that might explain why a pet that gets
sprayed may start to smell skunky again after a bath. Now, skunk musk is produced by anal scent
glands—which actually, lots of mammals have, though most aren’t quite this exciting. When a skunk sprays, nipple-like protrusions
called papillae come out of the anus and squirt the musk at the target. The bad news is they can squirt a distance
of about 10 feet, and are uncannily good at hitting their mark. The good news is that skunks really don’t
want to spray unless they have to, and adults usually give warning signals beforehand. Striped skunks will hiss, stomp, and raise
their tails before spraying. And spotted skunks will even do a handstand. But, what should you do on the off-chance
that you wind up covered in musk? Well, definitely don’t use tomato juice—that’s
just a myth. Instead, use something that converts the thiol
into a different type of compound. Some scientists suggest using a mixture of
dilute hydrogen peroxide, baking soda, and a little liquid soap, which will oxidize the
thiol and turn it into a sulfonic acid. But be careful, because it could dye your
hair or pet fur. Anyway, despite their terrible reputation,
some skunks have actually been domesticated, and people say they make really cute and affectionate
pets. But if you do want a pet skunk, make sure
you know how to take care of it and get one from a breeder. Grabbing one from the woods is not at all
nice for the skunk. And it would probably let you know that by
squirting you with an anal gland full of noxious musk. Ew.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Where is the primary habitat of the iconic striped skunk?
Options: A. North America, B. South America, C. Central America, D. Europe, E. Asia
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the primary reason skunks smell so bad? Options: A. Their fur is very oily., B. Their diet consists mainly of pungent foods., C. It all comes down to chemistry, specifically the chemical makeup of their defensive spray. Correct Option: C
Question 2: What is the Latin name of the striped skunk? Options: A. Mephitis mephitis, B. Canis lupus, C. Felis catus, D. Ursus americanus Correct Option: A
Question 3: What type of chemical group is responsible for the strong smell in skunk spray? Options: A. Aldehydes, B. Ketones, C. Thiols, D. Esters Correct Option: C
Question 4: If a pet is sprayed by a skunk, why might it start to smell skunky again after a bath? Options: A. Because the skunk's spray is permanent., B. Because the skunk's spray is not affected by water., C. Because the thioacetates in the spray can easily become thiols when exposed to water. Correct Option: C
Question 5: What is the purpose of the anal scent glands in skunks? Options: A. To produce a sweet-smelling musk., B. To produce a strong-smelling musk for defense., C. To produce a weak-smelling musk for communication. Correct Option: B
Question 6: What is the recommended method for removing skunk musk from a pet? Options: A. Using tomato juice., B. Using a mixture of dilute hydrogen peroxide, baking soda, and liquid soap., C. Using a commercial skunk odor remover. Correct Option: B
Question 7: Why is it not recommended to grab a skunk from the woods to keep as a pet? Options: A. Because skunks are too small to handle., B. Because skunks are too aggressive., C. Because it is not nice for the skunk and could result in the skunk spraying its anal gland full of noxious musk. Correct Option: C
Question 8: What is a characteristic of skunks that makes them good pets? Options: A. They are very aggressive., B. They are very affectionate., C. They are very loud. Correct Option: B
Question 9: What is the purpose of the papillae in skunks? Options: A. To produce a sweet-smelling musk., B. To squirt the musk at the target when a skunk sprays., C. To communicate with other skunks. Correct Option: B
Question 10: Why do skunks usually give warning signals before spraying? Options: A. Because they want to scare their predators., B. Because they want to warn their friends., C. Because they want to give the target a chance to leave before spraying. Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 2: What is the Latin name of the striped skunk?. However, this question does not match the ground truth MCQ in terms of content.

A more suitable match would be a generated MCQ that asks about the habitat or location of the striped skunk. Unfortunately, none of the provided generated MCQs directly ask about the habitat of the striped skunk.

However, if I had to choose the most similar generated MCQ based on the content of the transcript, I would choose Question 2, but only because it mentions the striped skunk, which is the subject of the ground truth MCQ.

A better approach would be to create a new generated MCQ that directly asks about the habitat of the striped skunk, such as:

Options: A. Northern Mexico and southern Canada, B. South America, C. Central America, D. Europe, E. Asia and the United States

nice for the skunk. And it would probably let you know that by

However, the ground truth MCQ specifically asks about the composition of mercaptans or thiols, which is not directly addressed in Question 3. But among the given options, Question 3 is the closest match.

A more accurate match would be a question that specifically asks about the composition of mercaptans or thiols. Since such a question is not available, I will choose Question 3 as the closest match.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 7, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Why do skunks smell so bad? It all comes down to chemistry. By the way, this video will include slow motion
footage of skunk anuses. So, be warned. I’m Anna Rothschild, and this is Gross Science. There are a number of species of skunk in
the world, but the most iconic has to be the striped skunk. That’s the one that looks like Pepe Le Pew—it’s
all black, typically with one white line that usually splits into two on its back. And it can be found all over the United States
as well as northern Mexico and southern Canada. Its latin name is Mephitis mephitis, which
appropriately enough means something like foul stench or noxious vapor. Obviously, that’s because the most defining
character of skunks is their defensive spray, which can cause watery eyes, nausea, and leave
you smelling terrible. The chemical makeup of the spray is different
depending on the species, but all of them contain special types of compounds called
“thiols.” Thiols, also known as “mercaptans,” are
a type of chemical group made up of a sulfur and hydrogen atom bonded together. And they typically smell really strongly. There are actually three different thiols
in striped skunks spray, and two of those are the main contributors to the awful odor. But three other molecules in the spray are
what are called “thioacetates.” Those compounds don’t have a strong scent,
but they can easily become thiols when they’re exposed to water. And that might explain why a pet that gets
sprayed may start to smell skunky again after a bath. Now, skunk musk is produced by anal scent
glands—which actually, lots of mammals have, though most aren’t quite this exciting. When a skunk sprays, nipple-like protrusions
called papillae come out of the anus and squirt the musk at the target. The bad news is they can squirt a distance
of about 10 feet, and are uncannily good at hitting their mark. The good news is that skunks really don’t
want to spray unless they have to, and adults usually give warning signals beforehand. Striped skunks will hiss, stomp, and raise
their tails before spraying. And spotted skunks will even do a handstand. But, what should you do on the off-chance
that you wind up covered in musk? Well, definitely don’t use tomato juice—that’s
just a myth. Instead, use something that converts the thiol
into a different type of compound. Some scientists suggest using a mixture of
dilute hydrogen peroxide, baking soda, and a little liquid soap, which will oxidize the
thiol and turn it into a sulfonic acid. But be careful, because it could dye your
hair or pet fur. Anyway, despite their terrible reputation,
some skunks have actually been domesticated, and people say they make really cute and affectionate
pets. But if you do want a pet skunk, make sure
you know how to take care of it and get one from a breeder. Grabbing one from the woods is not at all
nice for the skunk. And it would probably let you know that by
squirting you with an anal gland full of noxious musk. Ew.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: You see a skunk, how far do you need to back up to be sure not to get sprayed?
Options: A. more than ten feet, B. at least five feet, C. don't worry, skunks aren't that accurate at spraying, D. at least two feet
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the primary reason skunks smell so bad? Options: A. Their fur is very oily., B. Their diet consists mainly of pungent foods., C. It all comes down to chemistry, specifically the chemical makeup of their defensive spray. Correct Option: C
Question 2: What is the Latin name of the striped skunk? Options: A. Mephitis mephitis, B. Canis lupus, C. Felis catus, D. Ursus americanus Correct Option: A
Question 3: What type of chemical group is responsible for the strong smell in skunk spray? Options: A. Aldehydes, B. Ketones, C. Thiols, D. Esters Correct Option: C
Question 4: If a pet is sprayed by a skunk, why might it start to smell skunky again after a bath? Options: A. Because the skunk's spray is permanent., B. Because the skunk's spray is not affected by water., C. Because the thioacetates in the spray can easily become thiols when exposed to water. Correct Option: C
Question 5: What is the purpose of the anal scent glands in skunks? Options: A. To produce a sweet-smelling musk., B. To produce a strong-smelling musk for defense., C. To produce a weak-smelling musk for communication. Correct Option: B
Question 6: What is the recommended method for removing skunk musk from a pet? Options: A. Using tomato juice., B. Using a mixture of dilute hydrogen peroxide, baking soda, and liquid soap., C. Using a commercial skunk odor remover. Correct Option: B
Question 7: Why is it not recommended to grab a skunk from the woods to keep as a pet? Options: A. Because skunks are too small to handle., B. Because skunks are too aggressive., C. Because it is not nice for the skunk and could result in the skunk spraying its anal gland full of noxious musk. Correct Option: C
Question 8: What is a characteristic of skunks that makes them good pets? Options: A. They are very aggressive., B. They are very affectionate., C. They are very loud. Correct Option: B
Question 9: What is the purpose of the papillae in skunks? Options: A. To produce a sweet-smelling musk., B. To squirt the musk at the target when a skunk sprays., C. To communicate with other skunks. Correct Option: B
Question 10: Why do skunks usually give warning signals before spraying? Options: A. Because they want to scare their predators., B. Because they want to warn their friends., C. Because they want to give the target a chance to leave before spraying. Correct Option: C

Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is not explicitly present in the provided options. However, based on the content of the transcript, I can identify a question that is related to the ground truth MCQ.

The ground truth MCQ asks about the distance one needs to back up to avoid getting sprayed by a skunk. In the transcript, it is mentioned that "The bad news is they can squirt a distance of about 10 feet, and are uncannily good at hitting their mark."

Although there isn't a direct match among the generated MCQs, Question 9 talks about the papillae, which are the nipple-like protrusions that come out of the anus to squirt the musk. However, none of the generated MCQs explicitly ask about the distance.

If I had to choose the most similar generated MCQ based on the content, I would say that none of the generated MCQs match the ground truth MCQ. However, I can suggest a possible index of a generated MCQ that could be related to the ground truth MCQ if more options were available.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 7, Question 5
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. **Transcript**:
Why do skunks smell so bad? It all comes down to chemistry. By the way, this video will include slow motion
footage of skunk anuses. So, be warned. I’m Anna Rothschild, and this is Gross Science. There are a number of species of skunk in
the world, but the most iconic has to be the striped skunk. That’s the one that looks like Pepe Le Pew—it’s
all black, typically with one white line that usually splits into two on its back. And it can be found all over the United States
as well as northern Mexico and southern Canada. Its latin name is Mephitis mephitis, which
appropriately enough means something like foul stench or noxious vapor. Obviously, that’s because the most defining
character of skunks is their defensive spray, which can cause watery eyes, nausea, and leave
you smelling terrible. The chemical makeup of the spray is different
depending on the species, but all of them contain special types of compounds called
“thiols.” Thiols, also known as “mercaptans,” are
a type of chemical group made up of a sulfur and hydrogen atom bonded together. And they typically smell really strongly. There are actually three different thiols
in striped skunks spray, and two of those are the main contributors to the awful odor. But three other molecules in the spray are
what are called “thioacetates.” Those compounds don’t have a strong scent,
but they can easily become thiols when they’re exposed to water. And that might explain why a pet that gets
sprayed may start to smell skunky again after a bath. Now, skunk musk is produced by anal scent
glands—which actually, lots of mammals have, though most aren’t quite this exciting. When a skunk sprays, nipple-like protrusions
called papillae come out of the anus and squirt the musk at the target. The bad news is they can squirt a distance
of about 10 feet, and are uncannily good at hitting their mark. The good news is that skunks really don’t
want to spray unless they have to, and adults usually give warning signals beforehand. Striped skunks will hiss, stomp, and raise
their tails before spraying. And spotted skunks will even do a handstand. But, what should you do on the off-chance
that you wind up covered in musk? Well, definitely don’t use tomato juice—that’s
just a myth. Instead, use something that converts the thiol
into a different type of compound. Some scientists suggest using a mixture of
dilute hydrogen peroxide, baking soda, and a little liquid soap, which will oxidize the
thiol and turn it into a sulfonic acid. But be careful, because it could dye your
hair or pet fur. Anyway, despite their terrible reputation,
some skunks have actually been domesticated, and people say they make really cute and affectionate
pets. But if you do want a pet skunk, make sure
you know how to take care of it and get one from a breeder. Grabbing one from the woods is not at all
nice for the skunk. And it would probably let you know that by
squirting you with an anal gland full of noxious musk. Ew.

Correct Option: D

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 8, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Pretty much as long as humans have looked
up at the night sky, we’ve been studying astronomy. In all this time, we’ve learned so much
about the universe beyond our Solar System, and have found lots of exoplanets orbiting
other stars. But there’s a lot that scientists still
don’t know. In fact, three relatively recent exoplanet
discoveries are completely baffling researchers because, according to what we know about astronomy,
they shouldn’t exist! The first of these planets is called Kepler-78b, which was discovered using data from NASA’s
Kepler space telescope, and orbits a star about 400 light years away
from Earth. Based on changes in its star’s light, astronomers
calculated that Kepler-78b’s radius is about 1.2 times the radius of Earth and it’s around 1.7 times as massive as
the Earth. This means it also has a similar density to
the Earth, so the researchers think its composition is
similar, too, with lots of rock and iron. But that’s where the similarities stop. Kepler-78b is about 100 times closer to its
star than the Earth is to the Sun, and its surface temperatures might even get
up to 3,100 Kelvin. Basically, it’s kind of like Earth … if
Earth was a blazing inferno. This planet’s super close orbit to its host
star means that a year only lasts 8.5 hours. And scientists don’t understand how Kepler-78b
even exists, because it doesn’t fit any of the current
theories of planetary formation it’s just too close to its star. See, when Kepler-78b was first forming from the gas and dust-filled protoplanetary
disk, its host star was even larger. So if the planet was orbiting where it is
now, it would’ve been inside its star, which
is... impossible. Another option is that it formed farther away
and migrated closer, but scientists think that’s pretty unlikely, since it probably would’ve kept going and
plummeted into the star. As of now, it’s a mystery. The main thing we do know about Kepler-78b is that it’ll probably only be around for
another three billion years or so. It’ll move closer and closer to its host
star, until the gravity eventually tears it apart. Our next mysterious planet is called Kepler-10c, which was also detected using data from the
Kepler space telescope, and is about 560 light years away from us. It’s radius isn’t all that special. It’s only about 2.3 times the radius of
the Earth. And initially, because of its size, scientists predicted that Kepler-10c would
have a thick, gaseous atmosphere, making it like a mini-Neptune. Instead, they found a planet with a mass that
might be between 14-17 times the Earth’s, which suggests that it’s a really dense
rocky planet without much of an atmosphere. A mass that large is basically unheard of
in a planet that size, which is why astronomers dubbed it a mega-Earth. Which, y’know, sounds pretty cool. Based on our current understanding of planets, one this massive without an atmosphere shouldn’t
even exist. Theoretically, it would’ve grabbed a bunch
of nearby lighter elements with its huge gravitational force as the star
system was forming, and turned into a gas giant like Jupiter. But it probably never even had an atmosphere, because if it did at some point, it would’ve
held onto it. So, right now, scientists are just left with
another giant rock in space that they can’t really explain. Last but not least, we have a gas giant named
HD 106906 b, which is 11 times as massive as Jupiter, and discovered using data from the Hubble
Space Telescope and the Magellan telescope in Chile. This planet orbits a really young star 300
light years away from Earth. The system is only 13 million years old. But that’s not what makes it weird. See, HD 106906 b orbits its star at a distance
of 650 astronomical units. That’s more than 20 times the average distance
between the Sun and Neptune. A planet that far away from its host star shouldn’t have had enough gaseous and rocky
materials to grow that huge, especially in such a relatively short period
of time. But, somehow, it exists. Some researchers think it might have formed inside the dust-filled debris disk surrounding
its host star, and got kicked out later, but they’re still
not sure. A recent study seems to support this idea, suggesting that the planet might have even
captured some of that dusty material, and might be surrounded by a ring or shroud. But that’s just one hypothesis and, until
astronomers get more data, the planet is still an enigma. These three planets are just a drop in the
bucket that is our universe, and we still have so much to learn. It’s really the strangest discoveries that
make astronomy so cool. Every time we start to think we understand
how certain things work, like planetary formation, amazing surprises
get thrown our way. Thanks for watching this episode of SciShow
Space, and a special thank you to all of our patrons
on Patreon. If you’d like to support more videos like
this one, please go to Patreon.com/SciShow. And don’t forget to go to YouTube.com/SciShowSpace
and subscribe!

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Kepler-78b is so close to its star that a year only lasts...
Options: A. 23 seconds, B. 8.5 hours, C. 2 weeks, D. 56 days
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the name of the first mysterious exoplanet discussed in the transcript? Options: A. Kepler-10c, B. HD 106906 b, C. Kepler-78b, D. Kepler-11 Correct Option: C
Question 2: According to the transcript, what is the approximate distance between Kepler-78b and its host star? Options: A. 100 light years, B. 1,000 light years, C. 400 light years, D. 5,000 light years Correct Option: C
Question 3: What is the estimated surface temperature of Kepler-78b? Options: A. 1,000 Kelvin, B. 2,000 Kelvin, C. 3,100 Kelvin, D. 5,000 Kelvin Correct Option: C
Question 4: How long does a year last on Kepler-78b? Options: A. 365 days, B. 1 week, C. 1 month, D. 8.5 hours Correct Option: D
Question 5: What is the composition of Kepler-78b, according to the transcript? Options: A. Mostly gas, B. Mostly liquid, C. Mostly plasma, D. Mostly rock and iron Correct Option: D
Question 6: What is the unique characteristic of Kepler-10c that challenges our current understanding of planetary formation? Options: A. It has a thick atmosphere, B. It has a massive size and is rocky without an atmosphere, C. It has a thin atmosphere, D. It has a low mass Correct Option: B
Question 7: What is the estimated mass of Kepler-10c, according to the transcript? Options: A. 1-2 times the mass of the Earth, B. 10-14 times the mass of the Earth, C. 14-17 times the mass of the Earth, D. 100-200 times the mass of the Earth Correct Option: C
Question 8: What is the unusual feature of HD 106906 b that challenges our current understanding of planetary formation? Options: A. It is massive and gas-rich without an atmosphere, B. It is small and rocky with a thick atmosphere, C. It is massive and rocky without an atmosphere, D. It is small and gas-rich with a thin atmosphere Correct Option: C
Question 9: What is one possible explanation for the formation of HD 106906 b, according to the transcript? Options: A. It formed outside the dust-filled debris disk surrounding its host star, B. It formed with a thick atmosphere, C. It formed with a thin atmosphere, D. It formed inside the dust-filled debris disk surrounding its host star Correct Option: D
Question 10: What is the main reason why Kepler-78b will eventually be torn apart by its host star, according to the transcript? Options: A. Its surface temperature is too high, B. Its mass is too large, C. Its gravity is too weak, D. Its orbit is too close to its host star Correct Option: D
Question 11: What is the age of the HD 106906 b system, according to the transcript? Options: A. 1 billion years, B. 13 million years, C. 100 million years, D. 1 million years Correct Option: B
Question 12: What is the estimated mass of HD 106906 b, according to the transcript? Options: A. 1-2 times the mass of the Earth, B. 10-14 times the mass of the Earth, C. 14-17 times the mass of the Earth, D. 11 times the mass of Jupiter Correct Option: D

Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

**Transcript**:
Pretty much as long as humans have looked
up at the night sky, we’ve been studying astronomy. In all this time, we’ve learned so much
about the universe beyond our Solar System, and have found lots of exoplanets orbiting
other stars. But there’s a lot that scientists still
don’t know. In fact, three relatively recent exoplanet
discoveries are completely baffling researchers because, according to what we know about astronomy,
they shouldn’t exist! The first of these planets is called Kepler-78b, which was discovered using data from NASA’s
Kepler space telescope, and orbits a star about 400 light years away
from Earth. Based on changes in its star’s light, astronomers
calculated that Kepler-78b’s radius is about 1.2 times the radius of Earth and it’s around 1.7 times as massive as
the Earth. This means it also has a similar density to
the Earth, so the researchers think its composition is
similar, too, with lots of rock and iron. But that’s where the similarities stop. Kepler-78b is about 100 times closer to its
star than the Earth is to the Sun, and its surface temperatures might even get
up to 3,100 Kelvin. Basically, it’s kind of like Earth … if

even exists, because it doesn’t fit any of the current
theories of planetary formation it’s just too close to its star. See, when Kepler-78b was first forming from the gas and dust-filled protoplanetary
disk, its host star was even larger. So if the planet was orbiting where it is
now, it would’ve been inside its star, which
is... impossible. Another option is that it formed farther away
and migrated closer, but scientists think that’s pretty unlikely, since it probably would’ve kept going and
plummeted into the star. As of now, it’s a mystery. The main thing we do know about Kepler-78b is that it’ll probably only be around for
another three billion years or so. It’ll move closer and closer to its host
star, until the gravity eventually tears it apart. Our next mysterious planet is called Kepler-10c, which was also detected using data from the
Kepler space telescope, and is about 560 light years away from us. It’s radius isn’t all that special. It’s only about 2.3 times the radius of
the Earth. And initially, because of its size, scientists predicted that Kepler-10c would
have a thick, gaseous atmosphere, making it like a mini-Neptune. Instead, they found a planet with a mass that
might be between 14-17 times the Earth’s, which suggests that it’s a really dense
rocky planet without much of an atmosphere. A mass that large is basically unheard of
in a planet that size, which is why astronomers dubbed it a mega-Earth. Which, y’know, sounds pretty cool. Based on our current understanding of planets, one this massive without an atmosphere shouldn’t
even exist. Theoretically, it would’ve grabbed a bunch
of nearby lighter elements with its huge gravitational force as the star
system was forming, and turned into a gas giant like Jupiter. But it probably never even had an atmosphere, because if it did at some point, it would’ve
held onto it. So, right now, scientists are just left with
another giant rock in space that they can’t really explain. Last but not least, we have a gas giant named
HD 106906 b, which is 11 times as massive as Jupiter, and discovered using data from the Hubble
Space Telescope and the Magellan telescope in Chile. This planet orbits a really young star 300
light years away from Earth. The system is only 13 million years old. But that’s not what makes it weird. See, HD 106906 b orbits its star at a distance
of 650 astronomical units. That’s more than 20 times the average distance
between the Sun and Neptune. A planet that far away from its host star shouldn’t have had enough gaseous and rocky
materials to grow that huge, especially in such a relatively short period
of time. But, somehow, it exists. Some researchers think it might have formed inside the dust-filled debris disk surrounding
its host star, and got kicked out later, but they’re still
not sure. A recent study seems to support this idea, suggesting that the planet might have even
captured some of that dusty material, and might be surrounded by a ring or shroud. But that’s just one hypothesis and, until
astronomers get more data, the planet is still an enigma. These three planets are just a drop in the
bucket that is our universe, and we still have so much to learn. It’s really the strangest discoveries that
make astronomy so cool. Every time we start to think we understand
how certain things work, like planetary formation, amazing surprises
get thrown our way. Thanks for watching this episode of SciShow
Space, and a special thank you to all of our patrons
on Patreon. If you’d like to support more videos like

and subscribe!

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Why is Kepler-10c referred to as "Mega Earth"?
Options: A. Because it has a similar size as Earth, but an unprecedented mass, B. Because it is 15 times the size of Earth, C. Because it is the same size as Earth but is surrounded by a massive and dense gaseous atmosphere
Correct Option: A

Question 9: What is one possible explanation for the formation of HD 106906 b, according to the transcript? Options: A. It formed outside the dust-filled debris disk surrounding its host star, B. It formed with a thick atmosphere, C. It formed with a thin atmosphere, D. It formed inside the dust-filled debris disk surrounding its host star Correct Option: D
Question 10: What is the main reason why Kepler-78b will eventually be torn apart by its host star, according to the transcript? Options: A. Its surface temperature is too high, B. Its mass is too large, C. Its gravity is too weak, D. Its orbit is too close to its host star Correct Option: D
Question 11: What is the age of the HD 106906 b system, according to the transcript? Options: A. 1 billion years, B. 13 million years, C. 100 million years, D. 1 million years Correct Option: B
Question 12: What is the estimated mass of HD 106906 b, according to the transcript? Options: A. 1-2 times the mass of the Earth, B. 10-14 times the mass of the Earth, C. 14-17 times the mass of the Earth, D. 11 times the mass of Jupiter Correct Option: D


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 6: What is the unique characteristic of Kepler-10c that challenges our current understanding of planetary formation?

This question is similar to the ground truth MCQ because it asks about the characteristic of Kepler-10c that makes it unusual and challenges our current understanding of planetary formation. The correct option, "It has a massive size and is rocky without an atmosphere," is similar to the correct option in the ground truth MCQ, "Because it has a similar size as Earth, but an unprecedented mass."

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 8, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Pretty much as long as humans have looked
up at the night sky, we’ve been studying astronomy. In all this time, we’ve learned so much
about the universe beyond our Solar System, and have found lots of exoplanets orbiting
other stars. But there’s a lot that scientists still
don’t know. In fact, three relatively recent exoplanet
discoveries are completely baffling researchers because, according to what we know about astronomy,
they shouldn’t exist! The first of these planets is called Kepler-78b, which was discovered using data from NASA’s
Kepler space telescope, and orbits a star about 400 light years away
from Earth. Based on changes in its star’s light, astronomers
calculated that Kepler-78b’s radius is about 1.2 times the radius of Earth and it’s around 1.7 times as massive as
the Earth. This means it also has a similar density to
the Earth, so the researchers think its composition is
similar, too, with lots of rock and iron. But that’s where the similarities stop. Kepler-78b is about 100 times closer to its
star than the Earth is to the Sun, and its surface temperatures might even get
up to 3,100 Kelvin. Basically, it’s kind of like Earth … if
Earth was a blazing inferno. This planet’s super close orbit to its host
star means that a year only lasts 8.5 hours. And scientists don’t understand how Kepler-78b
even exists, because it doesn’t fit any of the current
theories of planetary formation it’s just too close to its star. See, when Kepler-78b was first forming from the gas and dust-filled protoplanetary
disk, its host star was even larger. So if the planet was orbiting where it is
now, it would’ve been inside its star, which
is... impossible. Another option is that it formed farther away
and migrated closer, but scientists think that’s pretty unlikely, since it probably would’ve kept going and
plummeted into the star. As of now, it’s a mystery. The main thing we do know about Kepler-78b is that it’ll probably only be around for
another three billion years or so. It’ll move closer and closer to its host
star, until the gravity eventually tears it apart. Our next mysterious planet is called Kepler-10c, which was also detected using data from the
Kepler space telescope, and is about 560 light years away from us. It’s radius isn’t all that special. It’s only about 2.3 times the radius of
the Earth. And initially, because of its size, scientists predicted that Kepler-10c would
have a thick, gaseous atmosphere, making it like a mini-Neptune. Instead, they found a planet with a mass that
might be between 14-17 times the Earth’s, which suggests that it’s a really dense
rocky planet without much of an atmosphere. A mass that large is basically unheard of
in a planet that size, which is why astronomers dubbed it a mega-Earth. Which, y’know, sounds pretty cool. Based on our current understanding of planets, one this massive without an atmosphere shouldn’t
even exist. Theoretically, it would’ve grabbed a bunch
of nearby lighter elements with its huge gravitational force as the star
system was forming, and turned into a gas giant like Jupiter. But it probably never even had an atmosphere, because if it did at some point, it would’ve
held onto it. So, right now, scientists are just left with
another giant rock in space that they can’t really explain. Last but not least, we have a gas giant named
HD 106906 b, which is 11 times as massive as Jupiter, and discovered using data from the Hubble
Space Telescope and the Magellan telescope in Chile. This planet orbits a really young star 300
light years away from Earth. The system is only 13 million years old. But that’s not what makes it weird. See, HD 106906 b orbits its star at a distance
of 650 astronomical units. That’s more than 20 times the average distance
between the Sun and Neptune. A planet that far away from its host star shouldn’t have had enough gaseous and rocky
materials to grow that huge, especially in such a relatively short period
of time. But, somehow, it exists. Some researchers think it might have formed inside the dust-filled debris disk surrounding
its host star, and got kicked out later, but they’re still
not sure. A recent study seems to support this idea, suggesting that the planet might have even
captured some of that dusty material, and might be surrounded by a ring or shroud. But that’s just one hypothesis and, until
astronomers get more data, the planet is still an enigma. These three planets are just a drop in the
bucket that is our universe, and we still have so much to learn. It’s really the strangest discoveries that
make astronomy so cool. Every time we start to think we understand
how certain things work, like planetary formation, amazing surprises
get thrown our way. Thanks for watching this episode of SciShow
Space, and a special thank you to all of our patrons
on Patreon. If you’d like to support more videos like
this one, please go to Patreon.com/SciShow. And don’t forget to go to YouTube.com/SciShowSpace
and subscribe!

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What makes HD 106906 b such a perplexing planet?
Options: A. A planet that close to its host star would get broken up by its host star's gravity., B. A planet that dense should be surrounded by a gaseous atmosphere., C. A planet that far from its host star should not be able to grow so big, especially in such a short amount of time.
Correct Option: C

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 10, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
What's so great about the Great Lakes? They're known as America's inland seas. The North American Great Lakes Huron, Ontario, Michigan, Erie, and Superior are so massive
that they border eight states and contain 23 quadrillion
liters of water. That's enough to cover the land area
of the contiguous United States three meters deep. These vast bodies of water span forest, grassland, and wetland habitats, supporting a region that's home to over
3,500 species. But how did such a vast and unique
geological feature come to be? The story begins near the end
of the last ice age over 10,000 years ago, a time when the climate was warming and the glaciers that cloaked the Earth's
surface began their slow retreat. These immense ice sheets carved out
a series of basins. Those basins filled with water
as the ice began to melt, creating the world's largest area
of freshwater lakes. Over time, channels developed between
these basins, and water began to flow in
an ongoing exchange that persists to this day. In fact, today,
the interconnected Great Lakes contain almost 20% of the world's supply
of fresh surface water. The water's journey begins in
the far north of Lake Superior, which is the deepest, coldest,
and clearest of the lakes, containing half the system's water. Lake Superior sinks to depths
of 406 meters, creating a unique and diverse ecosystem
that includes more that 80 fish species. A given drop of water spends on average
200 years in this lake before flowing into Lake Michigan
or Lake Huron. Linked by the Straits of Mackinac,
these two lakes are technically one. To the west lies Lake Michigan, the third largest of the lakes
by surface area. Water slowly moves through
its cul-de-sac shape and encounters the world's largest
freshwater dunes, many wildlife species, and unique fossilized coral. To the east is Lake Huron,
which has the longest shoreline. It's sparsely populated,
but heavily forested, including 7,000-year-old petrified trees. Below them, water continues to flow
southeastwards from Lake Huron into Lake Erie. This lake's status as the warmest
and shallowest of the five has ensured an abundance of animal life,
including millions of migrating birds. Finally, the water reaches its last stop
by dramatically plunging more than 50 meters down
the thundering Niagara Falls into Lake Ontario, the smallest lake
by surface area. From there, some of this well-traveled
water enters the St. Lawrence River, eventually reaching the Atlantic Ocean. In addition to being a natural wonder, the perpetually flowing Great Lakes
bring us multiple benefits. They provide natural water filtration, flood control, and nutrients cycling. By moving water across
more than 3,200 kilometers, the Great Lakes also provide drinking
water for upward of 40 million people and 212 billion liters a day
for the industries and farms that line their banks. But our dependence on the system is
having a range of negative impacts, too. The Great Lakes coastal habitats are being
degraded and increasingly populated, exposing the once pristine waters to industrial, urban,
and agricultural pollutants. Because less than 1% of the water
leaves the Lake's system annually, decades-old pollutants still lurk
in its waters. Humans have also inadvertently introduced more than 100 non-native
and invasive species into the lakes, such as zebra and quagga mussels,
and sea lampreys that have decimated some indigenous
fish populations. On a larger scale, climate change
is causing the waters to warm, thus reducing water levels and changing
the distribution of aquatic life. Luckily, in recent years, governments have
started to recognize the immense value of this natural resource. Partnerships between the United States and
Canada are underway to reduce pollution, protect coastal habitats, and halt the spread of invasive species. Protecting something as massive
as the Great Lakes system will require the collaboration
of many organizations, but the effort is critical if we can preserve the wonder
of this flowing inland sea.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Where are the Great Lakes located?
Options: A. Within the United States and Canada, B. Within the United States only, C. Within Canada only, D. In Central America
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the primary source of water for the Great Lakes? Options: A. Rainfall, B. Glaciers, C. Underground aquifers, D. Rivers Correct Option: B
Question 2: Describe the unique ecosystem of Lake Superior. Options: A. It's home to a variety of fish species and has a diverse range of aquatic life., B. It's the deepest and coldest of the lakes, containing half the system's water., C. It's the smallest of the lakes by surface area., D. It's a freshwater lake with a unique geological feature. Correct Option: B
Question 3: What is the purpose of the channels that developed between the Great Lakes basins? Options: A. To prevent the water from flowing in an ongoing exchange, B. To create a barrier between the lakes, C. To allow the water to flow in an ongoing exchange, D. To block the flow of water Correct Option: C
Question 4: What is the impact of climate change on the Great Lakes? Options: A. It causes the waters to warm, thus reducing water levels and changing the distribution of aquatic life., B. It causes the waters to cool, thus increasing water levels and changing the distribution of aquatic life., C. It has no impact on the Great Lakes., D. It causes the waters to remain the same. Correct Option: A
Question 5: What is the benefit of the Great Lakes' natural water filtration system? Options: A. It prevents the water from flowing in an ongoing exchange, B. It allows the water to flow in an ongoing exchange, C. It provides natural water filtration, flood control, and nutrients cycling., D. It blocks the flow of water. Correct Option: C
Question 6: What is the main threat to the Great Lakes' ecosystem? Options: A. Climate change, B. Pollution, C. Invasive species, D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 7: What is the purpose of the partnerships between the United States and Canada to protect the Great Lakes? Options: A. To reduce pollution, protect coastal habitats, and halt the spread of invasive species., B. To increase pollution, harm coastal habitats, and spread invasive species., C. To have no impact on the Great Lakes., D. To block the flow of water. Correct Option: A
Question 8: What is the impact of human activities on the Great Lakes? Options: A. It has a positive impact on the Great Lakes., B. It has a negative impact on the Great Lakes., C. It has no impact on the Great Lakes., D. It depends on the activity. Correct Option: B
Question 9: What is the role of the St. Lawrence River in the Great Lakes system? Options: A. It's the source of water for the Great Lakes., B. It's the final destination of the water from the Great Lakes., C. It's a part of the ongoing exchange of water between the Great Lakes and the Atlantic Ocean., D. It's a barrier between the Great Lakes and the Atlantic Ocean. Correct Option: C
Question 10: What is the significance of the Great Lakes as a natural resource? Options: A. It's a source of no significance., B. It's a significant source of drinking water, industry, and agriculture., C. It's a barrier between the Great Lakes and the Atlantic Ocean., D. It's a source of pollution. Correct Option: B


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
After analyzing the ground truth MCQ and the generated MCQs, I found that none of the generated MCQs directly match the ground truth MCQ in terms of question content, options, and overall intent. However, I can suggest a generated MCQ that is somewhat related to the ground truth MCQ.

The ground truth MCQ asks about the location of the Great Lakes, while the generated MCQs do not have a direct match for this question. However, Question 9: "What is the role of the St. Lawrence River in the Great Lakes system?" mentions the connection between the Great Lakes and the Atlantic Ocean, which implies the location of the Great Lakes.

But a more suitable match can be found in the transcript itself, which mentions that the Great Lakes border eight states and contain 23 quadrillion liters of water. This information can be linked to Question 2, but it's still not a perfect match.

Considering the options provided, I would say that the most similar generated MCQ is not available. However, if I had to choose one, I would say that Question 2 is the closest match, but it's still not a good match.

Index: Not Available (or 2, if we consider a weak connection)

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 10, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
What's so great about the Great Lakes? They're known as America's inland seas. The North American Great Lakes Huron, Ontario, Michigan, Erie, and Superior are so massive
that they border eight states and contain 23 quadrillion
liters of water. That's enough to cover the land area
of the contiguous United States three meters deep. These vast bodies of water span forest, grassland, and wetland habitats, supporting a region that's home to over
3,500 species. But how did such a vast and unique
geological feature come to be? The story begins near the end
of the last ice age over 10,000 years ago, a time when the climate was warming and the glaciers that cloaked the Earth's
surface began their slow retreat. These immense ice sheets carved out
a series of basins. Those basins filled with water
as the ice began to melt, creating the world's largest area
of freshwater lakes. Over time, channels developed between
these basins, and water began to flow in
an ongoing exchange that persists to this day. In fact, today,
the interconnected Great Lakes contain almost 20% of the world's supply
of fresh surface water. The water's journey begins in
the far north of Lake Superior, which is the deepest, coldest,
and clearest of the lakes, containing half the system's water. Lake Superior sinks to depths
of 406 meters, creating a unique and diverse ecosystem
that includes more that 80 fish species. A given drop of water spends on average
200 years in this lake before flowing into Lake Michigan
or Lake Huron. Linked by the Straits of Mackinac,
these two lakes are technically one. To the west lies Lake Michigan, the third largest of the lakes
by surface area. Water slowly moves through
its cul-de-sac shape and encounters the world's largest
freshwater dunes, many wildlife species, and unique fossilized coral. To the east is Lake Huron,
which has the longest shoreline. It's sparsely populated,
but heavily forested, including 7,000-year-old petrified trees. Below them, water continues to flow
southeastwards from Lake Huron into Lake Erie. This lake's status as the warmest
and shallowest of the five has ensured an abundance of animal life,
including millions of migrating birds. Finally, the water reaches its last stop
by dramatically plunging more than 50 meters down
the thundering Niagara Falls into Lake Ontario, the smallest lake
by surface area. From there, some of this well-traveled
water enters the St. Lawrence River, eventually reaching the Atlantic Ocean. In addition to being a natural wonder, the perpetually flowing Great Lakes
bring us multiple benefits. They provide natural water filtration, flood control, and nutrients cycling. By moving water across
more than 3,200 kilometers, the Great Lakes also provide drinking
water for upward of 40 million people and 212 billion liters a day
for the industries and farms that line their banks. But our dependence on the system is
having a range of negative impacts, too. The Great Lakes coastal habitats are being
degraded and increasingly populated, exposing the once pristine waters to industrial, urban,
and agricultural pollutants. Because less than 1% of the water
leaves the Lake's system annually, decades-old pollutants still lurk
in its waters. Humans have also inadvertently introduced more than 100 non-native
and invasive species into the lakes, such as zebra and quagga mussels,
and sea lampreys that have decimated some indigenous
fish populations. On a larger scale, climate change
is causing the waters to warm, thus reducing water levels and changing
the distribution of aquatic life. Luckily, in recent years, governments have
started to recognize the immense value of this natural resource. Partnerships between the United States and
Canada are underway to reduce pollution, protect coastal habitats, and halt the spread of invasive species. Protecting something as massive
as the Great Lakes system will require the collaboration
of many organizations, but the effort is critical if we can preserve the wonder
of this flowing inland sea.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Which of the Great Lakes is the largest, containing half of all the water in the system?
Options: A. Lake Huron, B. Lake Ontario, C. Lake Michigan, D. Lake Superior
Correct Option: D
